thread.title: H.S. girls volleyball: Mahwah tops Secaucus - Girls Volleyball
thread.title_full: H.S. girls volleyball: Mahwah tops Secaucus - Girls Volleyball - NorthJersey.com

author: JIM HAGUE
title: H.S. girls volleyball: Mahwah tops Secaucus - Girls Volleyball
text:
SECAUCUS — After the Mahwah girls volleyball team rolled off the team bus and strolled into the gym at Secaucus on Wednesday afternoon, coach Dean Rayside told his team to take a good look around at the walls of the gym.
Everywhere you turned, there was a banner honoring the most decorated program in New Jersey history, with 20 state championships to go along with countless division and county titles.
"I showed them Secaucus's championship pedigree," Rayside said. "They were coming off an emotional high [Tuesday] beating Ramapo, so I wanted to see how they could handle it."
The message was received — loud and clear.
"We knew that they were a really good team," said sophomore Caelin Jaskot. "After we saw all the banners, we didn't let it get to us. We just had to come out and play our game. It was our job to not notice what was around us and focus on the game."
That's what the Thunderbirds did, with junior middle hitter Tabitha Paul supplying the thunder with her hits and kills, and Jaskot flying all over the place, making an assortment of plays, leading the Thunderbirds to a convincing win, 25-21, 25-20.
The victory enabled Mahwah to improve to 7-2, while the Patriots, the defending Group 1 champions, dropped to an uncharacteristic 7-3.
The Thunderbirds won the first game behind the solid net play of Paul, who helped Mahwah take control of the game with consecutive plays at the net to make the score 17-12, and Danielle Petrovic added a service ace to push the lead to 18-12.
The Patriots sliced the lead to 20-17 thanks to the fine play at net by Alyson Toman. But then the T-Birds scored four straight points, keyed by two service aces from Britni Jaskot, Caelin's older sister, to take a 24-17 lead and held off a Patriot surge to collect the win.
The second game was all Secaucus in the early going, as the Patriots jumped out to a 6-3 lead and then increased the advantage to 12-8.
That's when Rayside summoned Paul off the bench and that move turned the game around, as the dominating player registered two straight kills.
Secaucus managed to take a 16-11 lead, then Paul took over again, keying a 6-1 run that included five straight points.
"Having Tabitha at the net takes a lot of the weight off my shoulders," Caelin Jaskot said. "It's good to know that you have such a good hitter up front."
Paul's domination at the net just emotionally deflates the opponent.
"It's an exciting feeling," Paul said. "It's important to me, because I want us all to be able to hit like that. I push myself, knowing that if the ball comes to me, I can put the ball away."
The loss didn't come as a surprise to Secaucus coach Sheila Rivera. The Patriots started four freshmen in their lineup, so they're undergoing some growing pains.
Toman led the way with 13 kills and was equally tough at the net. Alexandra Ianuale, one of the four freshman starters, had nine assists, and Kristina Ulrich had nine digs.
Mahwah knows that there is a lot of season remaining, but the Thunderbirds have to be pleased where they're nesting. "As a team, we beat Ramapo and now Secaucus," Paul said. "We can beat anybody."
